documents.title: GoC H1 2026 Product Prioritization - WIP
documents.content:
Ôªø2026 Strategy

FTEs: 8 devs (3 parental fill, 2 backfills) ‚Üí Q2 7 FE devs (+ 1EM +2 POs) + [new] 2 FE devs + 1 BE 

Q1: 7 FE devs (Himash, Becca, Romi, Pame, Nvard, Chi, Madeeha)

Q2: +2 FE devs, Bolo & Richa back (11 total FEs), 1 BE (TBD)

H2 2025 Reflection

In H2 2025, our product strategy was designed to address unrecovered Conversion Rates (CR) and declining Active Order Rates (AOR). For CR, we successfully launched the Reactivation page revamp and are on progress to launch the One Time Purchase experiment. On the AOR side, we drove Free Add-on take rates to over 90% consistently by closing gaps in the selection and persistence experience, and launched Charge at Checkout.

1. Reactivation Page Revamp. We launched a new, mobile-first reactivation page that reduces the page length by one third with improvements on information architecture and clearer call to action. Also, customers can now choose their free add-ons directly on the reactivation page, instead of after reactivating their accounts. These changes are foundational to run more free for life reactivation campaigns including turkeys on Thanksgiving  (+20% CR YoY). However, some critical features were de-prioritized such as the ability to change cadence and reschedule directly on the reactivation page. 

2. One-Time Purchases (OTP). The technical solution for OTP pivoted from the initial MVP hack to the proper solution due to a technical blocker from CRM as well as higher confidence in the new endpoint following HF rollouts. While this solution saves time in the long-term, the launch week is delayed (likely W2‚Äô2026 - TBC) due to additional time for another technical investigation and (unplanned) capacity constraints.

3. Closing Free Add-on Take Rate. By October we finally reached +90% free add-on take rate for both new and active users consistently. Persisting free add-ons (+40% active TR), developing the multi-add-on pop-up on funnel and reactivation (+5% TR), and migrating bundle offers to Wallet (4.2k customers). While it‚Äôs great that we finally closed down the Wallet take rate gap, a significant portion of Q3 engineering capacity was allocated, which was not originally accounted for in the H2 roadmap.

4. Charge at Checkout. By charging customers at checkout instead of at cut-off, we aim to improve empty conversions and acceptance rates, thereby positively impacting overall delivered orders.





Learnings: 

* Better resource planning for adhoc and technical initiatives needed: We only executed on 2 out of 5 key strategies referenced in the previous strategy document with projects such as the Pricing Value Experiment getting pushed to next year. When planning for H2 2025, we did not initially account for initiatives such as Subscribable free add ons, as well as more tactical initiatives like 2-week cadence or legal compliance initiatives in the (cancellation) funnel. Engineering capacity was also impacted around September-October due to personnel changes, including one transfer to TPT and two individuals taking parental leave. We also need to proactively account for resourcing technical initiatives such as endpoint deprecations and migrations.

* More space needed for iterations: there are initiatives such as Seamless and Search with clear next iterations, however instead of building these we focused on building new initiatives. This delays implementing these learnings and therefore realization of business value. Doing these next iterations with too much time in between can also lengthen development as the team has to re-learn the technical context for the next itera



th new delivery options with 1 day cutoff

[q]i think this should be dependent on OTP leads results

[r]how come? I don't think the learnings from Leads test will necessarily transfer





It could work better because cancelled customers might have already experienced first-hand that subscription does not work 





We could even think about targeting specifically customers that have churned due to delivery frequency reasons

[s]-> hesitation more from a BC perspective + no ability to discount





-> refer to HF test learnings

[t]~10% cancel for "lifestyle" reason (="sub doens't work for me")

[u]1 total reaction

Yury Trofimov reacted with üòò at 2025-12-02 19:28 PM

[v]that can be a significant lever for AOR and PC2 improvement, should we move fw knowing that part of it will be unlocked with the value test

[w]open to continuing price/value exp hack

[x]lay out limitations with hacks (eg roll out strategy)

[y]1 total reaction

Marina Guthmann reacted with ‚ô•Ô∏è at 2025-12-03 15:40 PM

[z]potentially already planned for CDP v2 to fix data lag

[aa]it would be interesting to sequence the rebranding with value driven initiatives, such as richer PDPs. so we can collaborate with mktg on how to tackle the changes' communications

[ab]in the end if we want to do this well and continue highlighting new products, new deals, we eventually need to find a way to showcase surcharge cuts pre-checkout





I'm wondering if we should re-test surcharge pre-checkout but as its own section/maybe even bringing the 2-step flow pre-checkout 





because if we find a good way to frame surcharge cuts and Deals pre-checkout, then we will have more merchandising we can do pre-checkout as well





EOS+transparent pricing also a criteria

[ac]already big reasons to buy for prospects - we could target this to actives

[ad]in the end if we want to do this well and continue highlighting new products, new deals, we eventually need to find a way to showcase surcharge cuts pre-checkout





I'm wondering if we should re-test surcharge pre-checkout but as its own section/maybe even bringing the 2-step flow pre-checkout 





because if we find a good way to frame surcharge cuts and Deals pre-checkout, then we will have more merchandising we can do pre-checkout as well





EOS+transparent pricing also a criteria

[ae]already big reasons to buy for prospects - we could target this to actives

documents.title: TPT_App_v1_Proposal.md
documents.content:
ÔªøThe Pets Table App v1: Notifications-First MVP

Date: 2025-12-11 Authors: Prateek Jajoo (PM), Nikita Gorshkov (Dir Product) Status: Proposal





________________





1. Purpose

The Pets Table (TPT) faces a critical retention challenge: our Average Order Rate (AOR) lags behind competitors like Farmer‚Äôs Dog and Ollie, largely due to the lack of proactive, mobile-first customer engagement. This proposal outlines a low-cost, high-velocity strategy to deploy a TPT native mobile app. By leveraging a "webview-first" architecture (React Native shell + existing web flows), we can bypass expensive native development to deliver v0 (Web Parity) and v1 (Push Notifications). The core value prop isn't the app interface itself, but the notification channel it unlocks‚Äîdriving customers back to the service for order management and upsells, projected to generate ~$1.5M in annualized incremental revenue.

2. Current State / Problem

"Out of sight, out of mind."





* Lagging AOR: TPT‚Äôs AOR is trailing key competitors who utilize native apps to maintain persistent screen real estate and habituation.

* Reactive vs. Proactive: Our current web-only experience relies on customers remembering to visit our site or opening emails (20-25% open rate). We lack a direct, proactive trigger to prompt timely order management.

* Friction: Logging into a mobile website is high-friction compared to biometric app login, discouraging frequent "snacking" interactions where add-on upsells occur.

3. Strategic Solution

Build "The Notification Vehicle" Instead of a costly, multi-quarter native app build, we propose a Webview-First Hybrid App.





* Strategy: Use the Client Platform‚Äôs new React Native infrastructure to wrap our existing mobile web experience.

* Philosophy: "The app is a notification delivery vehicle with a dashboard face. Everything else is a webview."

* Cost/Speed: Minimizes engineering effort by reusing 90% of existing web code. Focuses native development strictly on the "Unlock" features: Push Notifications and Biometric Login.

Core Experiences: v0 vs v1

Feature

	v0 Scope (POC)

	v1 Scope (The Unlock)

	Goal

	Parity & Presence

	Engagement & Revenue

	Core UI

	Full Webview Wrapper (Pixel-perfect recreation of mobile web)

	Webview + Native Navigation Shell

	Authentication

	Persistent Web Session (Cookie-based)

	Persistent Web Session (Cookie-based)

	Notifications

	None

	Rich Push Notifications (Transactional + Marketing)

	Dashboard

	Web View

	Native "Glanceable" Dashboard (Next Box Date, Status)

	Order Mgmt

	Web View

	Web View (Deep-linked from Notifications)

	Upsell

	Standard Web Flow

	Push-Triggered Upsell (e.g., "Add treats to box shipping tomorrow")

	



Detailed scope sheet: Google Sheet Link

4. Business Impact

Hypothesis: Notifications drive frequency; frequency drives AOR and AOV.

Benchmarks (Weekly TPT Updates)

* Current AOR: Lagging behind key competitors (Farmer's Dog, Ollie).

* Competitor Engagement: Apps drive ~2x session frequency vs. mobile web.

* Push Open Rates: 5-10x higher than Email.

Projected Lift (Annualized)

Lever

	Mechanism

	Conservative Impact

	Revenue Impact

	Order Recovery

	"Last chance to edit" & "Card failure" pushes

	+5% AOR (App Users)

	~$1.1M

	Add-on Upsell

	"New treat" & "Box shipping soon" pushes

	+$2 AOV (App Users)

	~$400K

	Total

	



	



	~$1.5M

	



Assumptions: ~50k Active Subs, 30% App Adoption, $80 Base AOV.

5. Technical Strategy

We will leverage the new HelloFresh Client Platform capabilities to avoid building from scratch.





* Shell: React Native "Container" provided by Client Platform.

* Bridge: Two-way communication between Native Shell and Webview (allowing the web page to trigger native push permission prompts).

* Notifications: Integrated with ABBA (HelloFresh's notification infrastructure) and Braze/CRM for campaign management.

* Documentation: Infrastructure Architecture

6. Recommendations

1. Proceed with v0/v1 Strategy: Prioritize the notification unlock over native feature parity to maximize speed to value.

2. Leverage Client Platform: Utilize the existing React Native shell infrastructure to minimize overhead.

3. Launch & Learn: Ship v1 to validate the +5% AOR hypothesis before investing in further native features (v2).





________________





References

* TPT App 2026 - NV <> Client Platform Sync

* 2026 HFG Domain Objectives - The Pets Table

* TPT Weekly Check-in Notes





________________









Automatically generated by Gemini on 2025-12-11

Automatically generated by Gemini on 2025-12-11





Two options for V0: 

1. Maximizing web views and customizing the website to look more like an app, which is the least effort option, 

2. Involves having one core page (the dashboard) built with React Native and the rest as web views.

Webview (V0) Only:

Requirements:

* We need to customize for Mobile: header & footer

   * This is unknown effort to a complicated web setup and shared code

* Customize further as the App store may not be allowed for fully webview app 

* Estimated effort 2-4 weeks for 1 engineer (Conservatively)

   * But if it goes above 2 months, we should see if we can should do react-native directly. 





Cons: 

* Web view performance is usually worse, 

* Extensive customizations, such as changing dashboard appearance, would be harder to implement with web views.

* Eventually, we need to move towards all react native so important to webview work may be redundant 

* (Ahmed) Uncertainty of whether deep links (notifications to a specific in-app location) will work with web views





Webview (V0) + React-native dashboard:

* Prioritize Dashboard features (change delivery, change recipe, see feeding guide) & Add-ons

   * Why? - Better performance and user experience for the critical dashboard page.

* Dependencies:  React native platform architecture up in Q2 - So may not even be possible at launch in Q2. 

   * Ahmed: Sync backwards with the relevant team for updates on the infrastructure timeline.

* Timeline: 4 months, with building potentially starting around mid-Q2.





Questions:

1. Is V0 having any measurable impact? - Without notifications

2. We need a page to push the App installation - Checkout page

	Persistent Web Session (Cookie-based)

	Notifications

	None

	Rich Push Notifications (Transactional + Marketing)

	Dashboard

	Web View

	Native "Glanceable" Dashboard (Next Box Date, Status)

	Order Mgmt

	Web View

	Web View (Deep-linked from Notifications)

	Upsell

	Standard Web Flow

	Push-Triggered Upsell (e.g., "Add treats to box shipping tomorrow")

	



Detailed scope sheet: Google Sheet Link

4. Business Impact

Hypothesis: Notifications drive frequency; frequency drives AOR and AOV.

Benchmarks (Weekly TPT Updates)

* Current AOR: Lagging behind key competitors (Farmer's Dog, Ollie).

* Competitor Engagement: Apps drive ~2x session frequency vs. mobile web.

* Push Open Rates: 5-10x higher than Email.

Projected Lift (Annualized)

Lever

	Mechanism

	Conservative Impact

	Revenue Impact

	Order Recovery

	"Last chance to edit" & "Card failure" pushes

	+5% AOR (App Users)

	~$1.1M

	Add-on Upsell

	"New treat" & "Box shipping soon" pushes

	+$2 AOV (App Users)

	~$400K

	Total

	



	



	~$1.5M

	



Assumptions: ~50k Active Subs, 30% App Adoption, $80 Base AOV.

5. Technical Strategy

We will leverage the new HelloFresh Client Platform capabilities to avoid building from scratch.





* Shell: React Native "Container"



A (HelloFresh's notification infrastructure) and Braze/CRM for campaign management.

* Documentation: Infrastructure Architecture

6. Recommendations

1. Proceed with v0/v1 Strategy: Prioritize the notification unlock over native feature parity to maximize speed to value.

2. Leverage Client Platform: Utilize the existing React Native shell infrastructure to minimize overhead.

3. Launch & Learn: Ship v1 to validate the +5% AOR hypothesis before investing in further native features (v2).





________________





References

* TPT App 2026 - NV <> Client Platform Sync

* 2026 HFG Domain Objectives - The Pets Table

* TPT Weekly Check-in Notes





________________









Automatically generated by Gemini on 2025-12-11





Two options for V0: 

1. Maximizing web views and customizing the website to look more like an app, which is the least effort option, 

2. Involves having one core page (the dashboard) built with React Native and the rest as web views.

Webview (V0) Only:

Requirements:

* We need to customize for Mobile: header & footer

   * This is unknown effort to a complicated web setup and shared code

* Customize further as the App store may not be allowed for fully webview app 

* Estimated effort 2-4 weeks for 1 engineer (Conservatively)

   * But if it goes above 2 months, we should see if we can should do react-native directly. 





Cons: 

* Web view performance is usually worse, 

* Extensive customizations, such as changing dashboard appearance, would be harder to implement with web views.

* Eventually, we need to move towards all react native so important to webview work may be redundant 

* (Ahmed) Uncertainty of whether deep links (notifications to a specific in-app location) will work with web views





Webview (V0) + React-native dashboard:

* Prioritize Dashboard features (change delivery, change recipe, see feeding guide) & Add-ons

   * Why? - Better performance and user experience for the critical dashboard page.

* Dependencies:  React native platform architecture up in Q2 - So may not even be possible at launch in Q2. 

   * Ahmed: Sync backwards with the relevant team for updates on the infrastructure timeline.

* Timeline: 4 months, with building potentially starting around mid-Q2.





Questions:

1. Is V0 having any measurable impact? - Without notifications

2. We need a page to push the App installation - Checkout page

documents.title: TPT_App_v1_Proposal.md
documents.content:
ÔªøThe Pets Table App v1: Notifications-First MVP

Date: 2025-12-11 Authors: Prateek JajooNikita GorshkovAhmed WagdiDaniel AriasStatus: Draft





________________





1. Purpose

The Pets Table (TPT) faces a critical retention challenge: our Average Order Rate (AOR) lags behind competitors like Farmer‚Äôs Dog and Ollie, largely due to the lack of proactive, mobile-first customer engagement. This proposal outlines a low-cost, high-velocity strategy to deploy a TPT native mobile app. By leveraging a "webview-first" architecture (React Native shell + existing  web flows), we can bypass expensive native development to deliver v0 (Web Parity) and v1 (Push Notifications). The core value prop isn't the app interface itself, but the notification channel it unlocks‚Äîdriving customers back to the service for order management and upsells, projected to generate ~$1.5M in annualized incremental revenue.

2. Current State / Problem

"Out of sight, out of mind."





* Lagging AOR: TPT‚Äôs AOR is trailing key competitors who utilize native apps to maintain persistent screen real estate and habituation.

* Reactive vs. Proactive: Our current web-only experience relies on customers remembering to visit our site or opening emails (20-25% open rate). We lack a direct, proactive trigger to prompt timely order management.

* Friction: Logging into a mobile website is high-friction compared to biometric app login, discouraging frequent "snacking" interactions where add-on upsells occur.

3. Strategic Solution

Build "The Notification Vehicle" Instead of a costly, multi-quarter native app build, we propose a Webview-First Hybrid App.





* Strategy: Use the Client Platform‚Äôs new React Native infrastructure to wrap our existing mobile web experience.

* Philosophy: "The app is a notification delivery vehicle with a dashboard face. Everything else is a webview."

* Cost/Speed: Minimizes engineering effort by reusing 90% of existing web code. Focuses native development strictly on the "Unlock" features: Push Notifications and Biometric Login.

Core Experiences: v0 vs v1

Feature

	v0 Scope (POC)

	v1 Scope (The Unlock)

	Goal

	Parity & Presence

	Engagement & Revenue

	Core UI

	Full Webview Wrapper (Pixel-perfect recreation of mobile web)

	Webview + Native Navigation Shell

	Authentication

	Persistent Web Session (Cookie-based)

	Persistent Web Session (Cookie-based)

	Notifications

	None

	Rich Push Notifications (Transactional + Marketing)

	Dashboard

	Web View

	Native "Glanceable" Dashboard (Next Box Date, Status)

	Order Mgmt

	Web View

	Web View (Deep-linked from Notifications)

	Upsell

	Standard Web Flow

	Push-Triggered Upsell (e.g., "Add treats to box shipping tomorrow")

	



Detailed scope sheet: Google Sheet Link

4. Business Impact

Hypothesis: Notifications drive frequency; frequency drives AOR and AOV.

Benchmarks (Weekly TPT Updates)

* Current AOR: Lagging behind key competitors (Farmer's Dog, Ollie).

* Competitor Engagement: Apps drive ~2x session frequency vs. mobile web.

* Push Open Rates: 5-10x higher than Email.

Projected Lift (Annualized)

Lever

	Mechanism

	Conservative Impact

	Revenue Impact

	Order Recovery

	"Last chance to edit" & "Card failure" pushes

	+5% AOR (App Users)

	~$1.1M

	Add-on Upsell

	"New treat" & "Box shipping soon" pushes

	+$2 AOV (App Users)

	~$400K

	Total

	



	



	~$1.5M

	



Assumptions: ~50k Active Subs, 30% App Adoption, $80 Base AOV.

5. Technical Strategy

We will leverage the new HelloFresh Client Platform capabilities to avoid building from scratch.





* Shell: React Native "Container" provided by Client Platform.

* Bridge: Two-way communication between Native Shell and Webview (allowing the web page to trigger native push permission prompts).

* Notifications: Integrated with ABBA (HelloFresh's notification infrastructure) and Braze/CRM for campaign management.

* Documentation: Infrastructure Architecture

6. Recommendations

1. Proceed with v0/v1 Strategy: Prioritize the notification unlock over native feature parity to maximize speed to value.

2. Leverage Client Platform: Utilize the existing React Native shell infrastructure to minimize overhead.

3. Launch & Learn: Ship v1 to validate the +5% AOR hypothesis before investing in further native features (v2).





________________





References

* TPT App 2026 - NV <> Client Platform Sync

* 2026 HFG Domain Objectives - The Pets Table

* TPT Weekly Check-in Notes





________________

documents.title: Proposal & Tech Breakdown for Launching RTE Brands on the Unified Mobile App (Project ABBA)
documents.content:
ÔªøProposal & Tech Breakdown for the All-Brands Base App (Project ABBA)





Author(s): Daniel Arias

	Last Updated: May 5, 2025

	Status: Approved

	WBD: Unification of Mobile App Tech Real Estate to Support All Brands

	Purpose

Scope

With a technical approach for the future state of our mobile app architecture now aligned, the purpose of this document is to more granularly audit all consumer-facing experiences across all HelloFresh Group mobile apps in order to assess the engineering effort and technical strategy teams should account for in their 2025 Yearly Planning when looking to contribute to RTE brands such as Factor.





For each consumer-facing experience, we will estimate the engineering cost of:

1. Updating existing core native iOS/Android modules to support RTE and related functionality 

2. Migrate existing React Native experiences to the Shared Modules cross-platform solution and extend functionality





Accounting for these engineering estimates, market-specific business needs and long-term team ownership, this document looks to propose a technical solution (ie: Extend Native Modules: vs. React Native) for each TRE along with an overall project timeline and resource costing proposal to help drive 2025 Yearly Planning dependency conversations across teams.

Context

In Q4 2024, Foundations alliance is leading a project to bootstrap the ‚ÄúShared Modules‚Äù repository, which enables teams across HelloTech to create cross-platform mobile experiences via React Native and import them into native mobile apps powered by the existing Swift and Kotlin codebases. Through this Shared Modules solution and infrastructure changes on existing native Swift and Kotlin platforms planned for H1 2025, an ‚ÄúAll-brands‚Äù mobile app architecture [source] will be available which supports cross-platform development and enables teams to contribute to all HFG brands‚Äô iOS and Android mobile apps.





  







Figure: Swift & Kotlin repos import modules from the ‚ÄúShared Modules‚Äù repo that are then compiled by unified release pipelines to publish native iOS & Android apps across all brands in the organization





With the option of cross-platform mobile development now unlocked across teams in 2025, consumer-facing alliances are now looking to be informed on engineering resources and strategies they should allocate for in their 2025 roadmaps in order to support RTE brands. 

________________





Proposed Project Roadmap





The following project roadmap and timeline was derived from product team roadmaps and engineering effort estimations (see Effort Breakdown) from all impacted alliances.

Timeline

Milestones listed here are further described in the following Milestones section. This timeline might be adjusted as teams re-evaluate effort estimates and align on work stream start dates.





  







A detailed view of this overall project roadmap can be found in Miro.

Milestones

	Summary

	Owner

	Ship a React Native module (via Shared Modules) as iOS/Android artifacts and import/run them on the existing iOS/Android repos.

	Foundations/Callstack 

	Nov 15, 2024

	2 ‚úÖ

	Internal Review of POC from external agency

	Final review of work delivered by Callstack. Depending on the end state, extra foundational work will be needed from Foundations and TAM such as full Zest support, 3rd party libs, testing infra

	Foundations

	Dec 6, 2024

	3 ‚úÖ

	Native repos can run Factor app
